awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Experimental Investigation of Morphodynamic Coupling between River Deltas and Marshes
awd_abstract_narration:
Experimental Investigation of Morphodynamic Coupling between River Deltas and Marshes

River deltas are important to society as population centers and infrastructure hubs for hundreds of millions of people. Most river deltas host vast marshes that are biodiversity hotspots, productive fisheries, effective storm protection, and that capture and store significant amounts of carbon. The processes by which river deltas and marshes grow and collapse as a function of rising sea level and sediment input are well known in isolation. However, there is a fundamental lack of understanding of how marshes and deltas interact. Do feedbacks between marsh and delta dynamics fundamentally influence the behavior of both? The researchers will build laboratory scale deltas subject to controlled environmental conditions that will interact with a newly developed marsh proxy that mimics key marsh properties at a reduced scale. These experiments will help reveal how river deltas and marshes interact over hundred to thousand year timescales under simple conditions, and provide insight into the land loss and subsidence problems that are currently affecting the Mississippi and other global river deltas. The project will broadcast experiments into K-12 classrooms in Louisiana, train a diverse group of researchers at University of Arkansas and Tulane University, and translate results into articles designed for public consumption through social media platforms.

The researchers will study how river deltas and marshes interact using physical laboratory experiments that will incorporate a novel marsh proxy. This marsh proxy will be added to deltaic experiments following a rule-based model of sedimentation based on the local elevation of the evolving deposit. For the first time, this will allow them to document how the internal dynamics of deltas are augmented by marshes that cover vast swaths of many delta plains. Through comparison to prior experiments that evolved in the absence of marshes, they will isolate surface dynamics, compactional subsidence patterns, and stratigraphic products of marsh-delta coupling. Quantitative theory developed in this study will aid prediction of marsh and deltas sustainability in the coming decades and enhance ability to interpret their strata for paleo-environmental records.  Research will be conducted by a diverse team (in gender, ethnicity, and career stage) including undergraduate and graduate students, and outreach to K-12 students. This project is jointly funded by the Geomorphology and Land-Use Dynamics Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Marshes border many rivers as they traverse delta plains. Many of the benefits of deltas come from marshes, including high biodiversity, productive fisheries, storm protection, and the capture and storage of significant amounts of carbon. While we already know a good deal about marsh growth and delta growth, we lack reliable methods to predict how marshes and deltas interact. To close this gap, we conducted a suite of physical experiments in which river channels self-organized to construct deltas while subject to aggradation of a marsh proxy. This proxy was deposited by rules developed by the ecology community. Experiments were designed to explore development of deltas over timescales that encompass hundreds of river avulsions and in a setting with long term pseudo-subsidence which facilitated the construction of deltaic strata. The project focused on five key questions. The questions and associated core findings include:

1)    How does marsh sedimentation influence the morphology, slope, and mass balance of deltas? We find that mud and plant material that accumulate in wetlands alters the elevation distribution of coastal regions and the spatial deposition of the river sediment. Specifically, marsh sedimentation decreases the slope of deltas, creating larger deltas by area, which can trap river supplied clastic sediment.

2)    How does marsh sedimentation influence channel morphology and how channels move? We find that the addition of the proxy alters how flow is partitioned in channels and floodplains: specifically, with marshes flow outside the channel is reduced and channels are deeper and longer. The channel beds in the experiment often exist below sea level in the terrestrial portion of the delta top, creating a reach of steady, non-uniform backwater flow. Ultimately, non-fluvial sedimentation produces channels which are more analogous to channels in global river deltas.

3)    Can we use sediment compaction of proxy marsh deposits in experimental deltas to improve our meso-timescale understanding of coastal subsidence patterns? Coastal and deltaic wetlands accumulate a compressible mixture of organic material and mud which is deposited by tides and/or overbank flooding from rivers. Over time, more sediment is delivered on top of the initially porous surface layers and they become compacted during burial, contributing to a downward movement of the land surface known as subsidence. Subsidence is a hazard that threatens infrastructure and worsens coastal flooding. We examined the patterns of subsidence in the experiments. We find that subsidence is significantly higher where these wetland sediments have recently been deposited and driven by their compaction in the very shallow subsurface.

4)    How do the internal (autogenic) dynamics of deltas influence the aerial extend of subsurface carbon reservoirs in coastal river deltas? Autogenic dynamics of terrestrial channels in marginal marine settings are a principal driver of local shoreline movement via channel relocation, which affects nearshore sediment accumulation over time. However, the influence of these dynamics on organic matter preservation in coastal river deltas is unknown. We show timescales that quantify channel mobility and sediment deposition exert a control on shoreline movement and, thus, preservation of organic material. This work highlights the importance of incorporating these autogenic dynamics into any predictions of the spatial extent of subsurface carbon stores in sedimentary environments.

5)    How does water discharge variability in rivers (flood climate) influence the wetland and delta systems, specifically their strata. We find that floods increase the mobility of river channels, smoothing out deltaic shorelines and reducing the transience of shorelines. Floods also result in steeper delta tops. These outcomes lead to narrower elevation windows on deltas that are conducive to marsh growth, and a reduced rate of transfer of organic matter to the geological record.

  Observations of this study will aid predictions for sustainability of critical coastal landforms in the coming decades. Planned river diversions are a critical management strategy for river deltas threatened by sea level rise. Our study suggests that channel and floodplain aggradation rates depend on the non-fluvial sedimentation occurring in the system. For example, wetland aggradation appears to decrease the rate of maximum channel aggradation and amount of overbank flow, so it is important to incorporate this into management plans.

Regarding the strata produced by deltas in the presence of marsh accumulation: River deltas are critical components in the global carbon cycle, functioning as significant long-term net carbon sinks. We highlight the natural variability in the fluxes tied to this budget, with implications for the subsurface extent of carbon- rich strata.

            Funds tied to this study supported a research team that was diverse in career stage, gender, and ethnicity and supported two PhD students and one Masters student. Further, this project provided a hand-on educational opportunity for high-school students at Sci-High in New Orleans, a predominately low-income school focused on STEM education. Finally, videos of all physical experiments are shared through YouTube for use in classes where delta processes are discussed.
